edges.to_node_long: A3 Concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air
edges.rationale: A1 includes emissions of PM2.5. As well as being emitted directly, particulate matter can be formed in the atmosphere from reactions between other pollutants, of which SO2, NOx, NMVOCs and NH3 are the most important.
edges.from_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants

edges.to_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
edges.rationale: Damaging nutrient nitrogen comes predominantly from ammonia (NH3) but partly nitrogen oxides (NOx) and long-range transport of air pollutants.
edges.from_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants

edges.to_node_long: A7 Area exposed to damaging levels of ammonia (NH3) in the atmosphere
edges.rationale: A1 includes emissions of NH3
edges.from_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants

edges.to_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
edges.rationale: A1 includes NOx and VOC emissions. Chemical reactions in the air involving NOX and VOCs produce the toxic gas O3.
edges.from_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants

edges.to_node_long: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations
edges.rationale: NOx emissions (A1) include NO2 so contributes to roadside concentrations.
edges.from_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants

edges.to_node_long: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
edges.rationale: Long-term exposure to particulate matter contributes to the risk of developing cardiovascular disease and lung cancer.
edges.from_node_long: A3 Concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5 ) in the air

edges.to_node_long: B3 State of the water environment
edges.rationale: Nutrients are a major cause of water bodies being at less than good ecological status and also affect drinking water quality. Nitrates account for 65% of the reasons for failure for those groundwaters that are protected for use for drinking water and are classed at poor status. Nitrate enters groundwater from diffuse pollution on land (mainly water run-off from agricultural land) or is deposited onto land from the air.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: D4 Relative abundance and distribution of widespread species
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: D5 Conservation status of our native species
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: D6 Abundance and distribution of priority species in England
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: E7 Healthy soils
edges.rationale: Excess deposition of NH3 on natural ecosystems causes nutrient enrichment and changes in vegetation and soils.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: G1 Changes in landscape and waterscape character
edges.rationale: Nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems

edges.to_node_long: A6 Exceedance of damaging levels of nutrient nitrogen deposition on ecosystems
edges.rationale: NH3 emissions can be deposited in soils or in rivers and lakes, for example, through rain. Resulting nutrient nitrogen deposition affects the nutrient levels and diversity of species in sensitive environments, for example, by encouraging algae growth in lakes and water courses.
edges.from_node_long: A7 Area exposed to damaging levels of ammonia (NH3) in the atmosphere

edges.to_node_long: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
edges.rationale: Ozone is a gas which is damaging to human health and can trigger inflammation of the respiratory tract, eyes, nose and throat as well as asthma attacks.
edges.from_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

edges.to_node_long: D1 Quantity, quality and connectivity of habitats
edges.rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation.
edges.from_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

edges.to_node_long: D5 Conservation status of our native species
edges.rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation.
edges.from_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

edges.to_node_long: E2 Volume of agricultural production
edges.rationale: Ozone can have adverse effects on the environment through oxidative damage to vegetation including crops.
edges.from_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)

edges.to_node_long: G7 Health and wellbeing benefits
edges.rationale: Short-term exposure to concentrations of NO2 can cause inflammation of the airways and increase susceptibility to respiratory infections and to allergens. NO2 can exacerbate the symptoms of those already suffering from lung or heart conditions.
edges.from_node_long: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations

edges.to_node_long: A4 Rural background concentrations of ozone (O3)
edges.rationale: NO2 is one of the precursors to O3.
edges.from_node_long: A5 Roadside nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations

edges.to_node_long: A1 Emissions for five key air pollutants
edges.rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector. Agriculture also contributes a small proportion to NMVOC and PM2.5 emissions.
edges.from_node_long: E3 Volume of inputs used in agricultural production

edges.rationale: Agricultural sources make up by far the largest component in the inventory for ammonia emissions with cattle manure management, manure applied to soils and inorganic fertilizers each accounting for 20% or more of the emissions from this sector.
